     397                 :             : 
     398         [ -  + ]:       33171 :     assert(!tx.IsCoinBase());

     400                 :       59109 :         const Coin& coin = view.AccessCoin(txin.prevout);

     402                 :             :         // This coin was checked in PreChecks and MemPoolAccept
     403                 :             :         // has been holding cs_main since then.
     404                 :       59109 :         Assume(!coin.IsSpent());

     407                 :             :         // If the Coin is available, there are 2 possibilities:
     408                 :             :         // it is available in our current ChainstateActive UTXO set,

     440                 :             :     // We put the arguments we're handed into a struct, so we can pass them
     441                 :             :     // around easier.
     442                 :             :     struct ATMPArgs {
     443                 :             :         const CChainParams& m_chainparams;
     444                 :             :         const int64_t m_accept_time;
     445                 :             :         const bool m_bypass_limits;
     446                 :             :         /*
     447                 :             :          * Return any outpoints which were not previously present in the coins
     448                 :             :          * cache, but were added as a result of validating the tx for mempool
     449                 :             :          * acceptance. This allows the caller to optionally remove the cache
     450                 :             :          * additions if the associated transaction ends up being rejected by
     451                 :             :          * the mempool.
     452                 :             :          */
     453                 :             :         std::vector<COutPoint>& m_coins_to_uncache;
     454                 :             :         /** When true, the transaction or package will not be submitted to the mempool. */

     456                 :             :         /** Whether we allow transactions to replace mempool transactions. If false,
     457                 :             :          * any transaction spending the same inputs as a transaction in the mempool is considered
     458                 :             :          * a conflict. */
     459                 :             :         const bool m_allow_replacement;
     460                 :             :         /** When true, allow sibling eviction. This only occurs in single transaction package settings. */
     461                 :             :         const bool m_allow_sibling_eviction;
     462                 :             :         /** When true, the mempool will not be trimmed when any transactions are submitted in
     463                 :             :          * Finalize(). Instead, limits should be enforced at the end to ensure the package is not
     464                 :             :          * partially submitted.
     465                 :             :          */
     466                 :             :         const bool m_package_submission;

     468                 :             :          * policies such as mempool min fee and min relay fee.
     469                 :             :          */
     470                 :             :         const bool m_package_feerates;
     471                 :             :         /** Used for local submission of transactions to catch "absurd" fees

     473                 :             :          * Any individual transaction failing this check causes immediate failure.

     588                 :             :     // Single transaction acceptance
     589                 :             :     MempoolAcceptResult AcceptSingleTransaction(const CTransactionRef& ptx, ATMPArgs& args) EXCLUSIVE_LOCKS_REQUIRED(cs_main);
     590                 :             : 
     591                 :             :     /**
     592                 :             :     * Multiple transaction acceptance. Transactions may or may not be interdependent, but must not
     593                 :             :     * conflict with each other, and the transactions cannot already be in the mempool. Parents must
     594                 :             :     * come before children if any dependencies exist.
     595                 :             :     */

     598                 :             :     /**

     602                 :             :      * and creates a PackageMempoolAcceptResult wrapping the result.

     617                 :             : private:
     618                 :             :     // All the intermediate state that gets passed between the various levels
     619                 :             :     // of checking a given transaction.
     620                 :             :     struct Workspace {
     621                 :       42786 :         explicit Workspace(const CTransactionRef& ptx) : m_ptx(ptx), m_hash(ptx->GetHash()) {}

     623                 :             :          * replace via sibling eviction. */

     635                 :             :         bool m_sibling_eviction{false};
     636                 :             :

     638                 :             :          * of the transaction and sigops. */

     644                 :             : 
     645                 :             :         /** If we're doing package validation (i.e. m_package_feerates=true), the "effective"
     646                 :             :          * package feerate of this transaction is the total fees divided by the total size of
     647                 :             :          * transactions (which may include its ancestors and/or descendants). */
     648                 :             :         CFeeRate m_package_feerate{0};

     657                 :             :     };
     658                 :             : 
     659                 :             :     // Run the policy checks on a given transaction, excluding any script checks.
     660                 :             :     // Looks up inputs, calculates feerate, considers replacement, evaluates
     661                 :             :     // package limits, etc. As this function can be invoked for "free" by a peer,
     662                 :             :     // only tests that are fast should be done here (to avoid CPU DoS).
     663                 :             :     bool PreChecks(ATMPArgs& args, Workspace& ws) EXCLUSIVE_LOCKS_REQUIRED(cs_main, m_pool.cs);
     664                 :             : 
     665                 :             :     // Run checks for mempool replace-by-fee, only used in AcceptSingleTransaction.
     666                 :             :     bool ReplacementChecks(Workspace& ws) EXCLUSIVE_LOCKS_REQUIRED(cs_main, m_pool.cs);
     667                 :             : 
     668                 :             :     // Enforce package mempool ancestor/descendant limits (distinct from individual
     669                 :             :     // ancestor/descendant limits done in PreChecks) and run Package RBF checks.

     674                 :             : 
     675                 :             :     // Run the script checks using our policy flags. As this can be slow, we should
     676                 :             :     // only invoke this on transactions that have otherwise passed policy checks.

     679                 :             :     // Re-run the script checks, using consensus flags, and try to cache the
     680                 :             :     // result in the scriptcache. This should be done after
     681                 :             :     // PolicyScriptChecks(). This requires that all inputs either be in our
     682                 :             :     // utxo set or in the mempool.

     685                 :             :     // Try to add the transaction to the mempool, removing any conflicts first.

     690                 :             :     // Submit all transactions to the mempool and call ConsensusScriptChecks to add to the script

     726                 :             : 
     727                 :             :     // Fields below are per *sub*package state and must be reset prior to subsequent
     728                 :             :     // AcceptSingleTransaction and AcceptMultipleTransactions invocations
     729                 :       41966 :     struct SubPackageState {
     730                 :             :         /** Aggregated modified fees of all transactions, used to calculate package feerate. */
     731                 :             :         CAmount m_total_modified_fees{0};
     732                 :             :         /** Aggregated virtual size of all transactions, used to calculate package feerate. */
     733                 :             :         int64_t m_total_vsize{0};

     735                 :             :         // RBF-related members
     736                 :             :         /** Whether the transaction(s) would replace any mempool transactions and/or evict any siblings.
     737                 :             :          * If so, RBF rules apply. */

     740                 :             :         CTxMemPool::setEntries m_all_conflicts;

     761                 :             : 
     762                 :       42755 : bool MemPoolAccept::PreChecks(ATMPArgs& args, Workspace& ws)
     763                 :             : {
     764                 :       42755 :     AssertLockHeld(cs_main);
     765                 :       42755 :     AssertLockHeld(m_pool.cs);
     766                 :       42755 :     const CTransactionRef& ptx = ws.m_ptx;
     767                 :       42755 :     const CTransaction& tx = *ws.m_ptx;
     768                 :       42755 :     const Txid& hash = ws.m_hash;
     769                 :             : 
     770                 :             :     // Copy/alias what we need out of args
     771                 :       42755 :     const int64_t nAcceptTime = args.m_accept_time;
     772                 :       42755 :     const bool bypass_limits = args.m_bypass_limits;
     773                 :       42755 :     std::vector<COutPoint>& coins_to_uncache = args.m_coins_to_uncache;
     774                 :             : 
     775                 :             :     // Alias what we need out of ws
     776                 :       42755 :     TxValidationState& state = ws.m_state;

     951         [ +  - ]:       36229 :     ws.m_iters_conflicting = m_pool.GetIterSet(ws.m_conflicts);
     952                 :             : 
     953                 :             :     // Note that these modifications are only applicable to single transaction scenarios;
     954                 :             :     // carve-outs are disabled for multi-transaction evaluations.
     955                 :       36229 :     CTxMemPool::Limits maybe_rbf_limits = m_pool.m_opts.limits;
     956                 :             : 
     957                 :             :     // Calculate in-mempool ancestors, up to a limit.
     958   [ +  +  +  + ]:       36229 :     if (ws.m_conflicts.size() == 1 && args.m_allow_carveouts) {
     959                 :             :         // In general, when we receive an RBF transaction with mempool conflicts, we want to know whether we
     960                 :             :         // would meet the chain limits after the conflicts have been removed. However, there isn't a practical
     961                 :             :         // way to do this short of calculating the ancestor and descendant sets with an overlay cache of
     962                 :             :         // changed mempool entries. Due to both implementation and runtime complexity concerns, this isn't
     963                 :             :         // very realistic, thus we only ensure a limited set of transactions are RBF'able despite mempool
     964                 :             :         // conflicts here. Importantly, we need to ensure that some transactions which were accepted using
     965                 :             :         // the below carve-out are able to be RBF'ed, without impacting the security the carve-out provides
     966                 :             :         // for off-chain contract systems (see link in the comment below).
     967                 :             :         //
     968                 :             :         // Specifically, the subset of RBF transactions which we allow despite chain limits are those which
     969                 :             :         // conflict directly with exactly one other transaction (but may evict children of said transaction),
     970                 :             :         // and which are not adding any new mempool dependencies. Note that the "no new mempool dependencies"
     971                 :             :         // check is accomplished later, so we don't bother doing anything about it here, but if our
     972                 :             :         // policy changes, we may need to move that check to here instead of removing it wholesale.
     973                 :             :         //
     974                 :             :         // Such transactions are clearly not merging any existing packages, so we are only concerned with
     975                 :             :         // ensuring that (a) no package is growing past the package size (not count) limits and (b) we are
     976                 :             :         // not allowing something to effectively use the (below) carve-out spot when it shouldn't be allowed
     977                 :             :         // to.
     978                 :             :         //
     979                 :             :         // To check these we first check if we meet the RBF criteria, above, and increment the descendant
     980                 :             :         // limits by the direct conflict and its descendants (as these are recalculated in
     981                 :             :         // CalculateMempoolAncestors by assuming the new transaction being added is a new descendant, with no
     982                 :             :         // removals, of each parent's existing dependent set). The ancestor count limits are unmodified (as
     983                 :             :         // the ancestor limits should be the same for both our new transaction and any conflicts).
     984                 :             :         // We don't bother incrementing m_limit_descendants by the full removal count as that limit never comes
     985                 :             :         // into force here (as we're only adding a single transaction).
     986         [ -  + ]:        1524 :         assert(ws.m_iters_conflicting.size() == 1);
     987                 :        1524 :         CTxMemPool::txiter conflict = *ws.m_iters_conflicting.begin();
     988                 :             : 
     989                 :        1524 :         maybe_rbf_limits.descendant_count += 1;
     990                 :        1524 :         maybe_rbf_limits.descendant_size_vbytes += conflict->GetSizeWithDescendants();
     991                 :             :     }
     992                 :             : 
     993   [ +  -  +  + ]:       36229 :     if (auto ancestors{m_pool.CalculateMemPoolAncestors(*entry, maybe_rbf_limits)}) {

     996                 :             :         // If CalculateMemPoolAncestors fails second time, we want the original error string.
     997         [ +  - ]:          98 :         const auto error_message{util::ErrorString(ancestors).original};
     998                 :             : 
     999                 :             :         // Carve-out is not allowed in this context; fail
    1000         [ +  + ]:          98 :         if (!args.m_allow_carveouts) {
    1001   [ +  -  +  - ]:           4 :             return state.Invalid(TxValidationResult::TX_MEMPOOL_POLICY, "too-long-mempool-chain", error_message);
    1002                 :             :         }
    1003                 :             : 
    1004                 :             :         // Contracting/payment channels CPFP carve-out:
    1005                 :             :         // If the new transaction is relatively small (up to 40k weight)
    1006                 :             :         // and has at most one ancestor (ie ancestor limit of 2, including
    1007                 :             :         // the new transaction), allow it if its parent has exactly the
    1008                 :             :         // descendant limit descendants. The transaction also cannot be TRUC,
    1009                 :             :         // as its topology restrictions do not allow a second child.
    1010                 :             :         //
    1011                 :             :         // This allows protocols which rely on distrusting counterparties
    1012                 :             :         // being able to broadcast descendants of an unconfirmed transaction
    1013                 :             :         // to be secure by simply only having two immediately-spendable
    1014                 :             :         // outputs - one for each counterparty. For more info on the uses for
    1015                 :             :         // this, see https://lists.linuxfoundation.org/pipermail/bitcoin-dev/2018-November/016518.html
    1016                 :          94 :         CTxMemPool::Limits cpfp_carve_out_limits{

    1019                 :          94 :             .descendant_count = maybe_rbf_limits.descendant_count + 1,

    1034                 :             :     // already calculated.

    1072                 :             : 
    1073                 :        1558 : bool MemPoolAccept::ReplacementChecks(Workspace& ws)
    1074                 :             : {
    1075                 :        1558 :     AssertLockHeld(cs_main);
    1076                 :        1558 :     AssertLockHeld(m_pool.cs);
    1077                 :             : 
    1078                 :        1558 :     const CTransaction& tx = *ws.m_ptx;
    1079                 :        1558 :     const uint256& hash = ws.m_hash;
    1080                 :        1558 :     TxValidationState& state = ws.m_state;
    1081                 :             : 
    1082                 :        1558 :     CFeeRate newFeeRate(ws.m_modified_fees, ws.m_vsize);
    1083                 :             :     // Enforce Rule #6. The replacement transaction must have a higher feerate than its direct conflicts.
    1084                 :             :     // - The motivation for this check is to ensure that the replacement transaction is preferable for
    1085                 :             :     //   block-inclusion, compared to what would be removed from the mempool.
    1086                 :             :     // - This logic predates ancestor feerate-based transaction selection, which is why it doesn't
    1087                 :             :     //   consider feerates of descendants.
    1088                 :             :     // - Note: Ancestor feerate-based transaction selection has made this comparison insufficient to
    1089                 :             :     //   guarantee that this is incentive-compatible for miners, because it is possible for a
    1090                 :             :     //   descendant transaction of a direct conflict to pay a higher feerate than the transaction that
    1091                 :             :     //   might replace them, under these rules.

    1259                 :             :     // Check again against the current block tip's script verification
    1260                 :             :     // flags to cache our script execution flags. This is, of course,
    1261                 :             :     // useless if the next block has different script flags from the
    1262                 :             :     // previous one, but because the cache tracks script flags for us it
    1263                 :             :     // will auto-invalidate and we'll just have a few blocks of extra
    1264                 :             :     // misses on soft-fork activation.
    1265                 :             :     //
    1266                 :             :     // This is also useful in case of bugs in the standard flags that cause
    1267                 :             :     // transactions to pass as valid when they're actually invalid. For
    1268                 :             :     // instance the STRICTENC flag was incorrectly allowing certain
    1269                 :             :     // CHECKSIG NOT scripts to pass, even though they were invalid.
    1270                 :             :     //
    1271                 :             :     // There is a similar check in CreateNewBlock() to prevent creating

    1273                 :             :     // transactions into the mempool can be exploited as a DoS attack.

    1534                 :             : 
    1535                 :             :         // Make the coins created by this transaction available for subsequent transactions in the
    1536                 :             :         // package to spend. If there are no conflicts within the package, no transaction can spend a coin
    1537                 :             :         // needed by another transaction in the package. We also need to make sure that no package
    1538                 :             :         // tx replaces (or replaces the ancestor of) the parent of another package tx. As long as we
    1539                 :             :         // check these two things, we don't need to track the coins spent.
    1540                 :             :         // If a package tx conflicts with a mempool tx, PackageMempoolChecks() ensures later that any package RBF attempt
    1541                 :             :         // has *no* in-mempool ancestors, so we don't have to worry about subsequent transactions in
    1542                 :             :         // same package spending the same in-mempool outpoints. This needs to be revisited for general
    1543                 :             :         // package RBF.
    1544         [ +  - ]:         736 :         m_viewmempool.PackageAddTransaction(ws.m_ptx);
    1545                 :             :     }
    1546                 :             : 
    1547                 :             :     // At this point we have all in-mempool ancestors, and we know every transaction's vsize.
    1548                 :             :     // Run the TRUC checks on the package.
    1549         [ +  + ]:         840 :     for (Workspace& ws : workspaces) {
    1550   [ +  -  +  + ]:         721 :         if (auto err{PackageTRUCChecks(ws.m_ptx, ws.m_vsize, txns, ws.m_ancestors)}) {
    1551   [ +  -  +  - ]:          10 :             package_state.Invalid(PackageValidationResult::PCKG_POLICY, "TRUC-violation", err.value());
    1552   [ +  -  +  - ]:          30 :             return PackageMempoolAcceptResult(package_state, {});
    1553                 :         721 :         }
    1554                 :             :     }
    1555                 :             : 
    1556                 :             :     // Transactions must meet two minimum feerates: the mempool minimum fee and min relay fee.
    1557                 :             :     // For transactions consisting of exactly one child and its parents, it suffices to use the
    1558                 :             :     // package feerate (total modified fees / total virtual size) to check this requirement.
    1559                 :             :     // Note that this is an aggregate feerate; this function has not checked that there are transactions
    1560                 :             :     // too low feerate to pay for themselves, or that the child transactions are higher feerate than
    1561                 :             :     // their parents. Using aggregate feerate may allow "parents pay for child" behavior and permit
    1562                 :             :     // a child that is below mempool minimum feerate. To avoid these behaviors, callers of
    1563                 :             :     // AcceptMultipleTransactions need to restrict txns topology (e.g. to ancestor sets) and check
    1564                 :             :     // the feerates of individuals and subsets.
    1565                 :         119 :     m_subpackage.m_total_vsize = std::accumulate(workspaces.cbegin(), workspaces.cend(), int64_t{0},

    1617                 :             : 
    1618                 :         294 : void MemPoolAccept::CleanupTemporaryCoins()
    1619                 :             : {
    1620                 :             :     // There are 3 kinds of coins in m_view:
    1621                 :             :     // (1) Temporary coins from the transactions in subpackage, constructed by m_viewmempool.
    1622                 :             :     // (2) Mempool coins from transactions in the mempool, constructed by m_viewmempool.
    1623                 :             :     // (3) Confirmed coins fetched from our current UTXO set.
    1624                 :             :     //
    1625                 :             :     // (1) Temporary coins need to be removed, regardless of whether the transaction was submitted.
    1626                 :             :     // If the transaction was submitted to the mempool, m_viewmempool will be able to fetch them from
    1627                 :             :     // there. If it wasn't submitted to mempool, it is incorrect to keep them - future calls may try
    1628                 :             :     // to spend those coins that don't actually exist.
    1629                 :             :     // (2) Mempool coins also need to be removed. If the mempool contents have changed as a result
    1630                 :             :     // of submitting or replacing transactions, coins previously fetched from mempool may now be
    1631                 :             :     // spent or nonexistent. Those coins need to be deleted from m_view.
    1632                 :             :     // (3) Confirmed coins don't need to be removed. The chainstate has not changed (we are
    1633                 :             :     // holding cs_main and no blocks have been processed) so the confirmed tx cannot disappear like
    1634                 :             :     // a mempool tx can. The coin may now be spent after we submitted a tx to mempool, but
    1635                 :             :     // we have already checked that the package does not have 2 transactions spending the same coin.
    1636                 :             :     // Keeping them in m_view is an optimization to not re-fetch confirmed coins if we later look up
    1637                 :             :     // inputs for this transaction again.
    1638         [ +  + ]:         528 :     for (const auto& outpoint : m_viewmempool.GetNonBaseCoins()) {
    1639                 :             :         // In addition to resetting m_viewmempool, we also need to manually delete these coins from
    1640                 :             :         // m_view because it caches copies of the coins it fetched from m_viewmempool previously.
    1641         [ +  - ]:         234 :         m_view.Uncache(outpoint);
    1642                 :         294 :     }
    1643                 :             :     // This deletes the temporary and mempool coins.
    1644                 :         294 :     m_viewmempool.Reset();
    1645                 :         294 : }
    1646                 :             : 
    1647                 :         294 : PackageMempoolAcceptResult MemPoolAccept::AcceptSubPackage(const std::vector<CTransactionRef>& subpackage, ATMPArgs& args)
    1648                 :             : {
    1649                 :         294 :     AssertLockHeld(::cs_main);
    1650                 :         294 :     AssertLockHeld(m_pool.cs);
    1651                 :         588 :     auto result = [&]() EXCLUSIVE_LOCKS_REQUIRED(::cs_main, m_pool.cs) {
    1652         [ +  + ]:         294 :         if (subpackage.size() > 1) {
    1653                 :          62 :             return AcceptMultipleTransactions(subpackage, args);
    1654                 :             :         }
    1655                 :         232 :         const auto& tx = subpackage.front();
    1656                 :         232 :         ATMPArgs single_args = ATMPArgs::SingleInPackageAccept(args);
    1657                 :         232 :         const auto single_res = AcceptSingleTransaction(tx, single_args);
    1658         [ +  + ]:         232 :         PackageValidationState package_state_wrapped;
    1659         [ +  + ]:         232 :         if (single_res.m_result_type != MempoolAcceptResult::ResultType::VALID) {
    1660   [ +  -  +  -  :         280 :             package_state_wrapped.Invalid(PackageValidationResult::PCKG_TX, "transaction failed");
                   +  - ]
    1661                 :             :         }

    1743                 :             :         // There are 3 possibilities: already in mempool, same-txid-diff-wtxid already in mempool,
    1744                 :             :         // or not in mempool. An already confirmed tx is treated as one not in mempool, because all
    1745                 :             :         // we know is that the inputs aren't available.
    1746   [ +  -  +  + ]:         259 :         if (m_pool.exists(GenTxid::Wtxid(wtxid))) {
    1747                 :             :             // Exact transaction already exists in the mempool.
    1748                 :             :             // Node operators are free to set their mempool policies however they please, nodes may receive
    1749                 :             :             // transactions in different orders, and malicious counterparties may try to take advantage of
    1750                 :             :             // policy differences to pin or delay propagation of transactions. As such, it's possible for
    1751                 :             :             // some package transaction(s) to already be in the mempool, and we don't want to reject the
    1752                 :             :             // entire package in that case (as that could be a censorship vector). De-duplicate the
    1753                 :             :             // transactions that are already in the mempool, and only call AcceptMultipleTransactions() with
    1754                 :             :             // the new transactions. This ensures we don't double-count transaction counts and sizes when
    1755                 :             :             // checking ancestor/descendant limits, or double-count transaction fees for fee-related policy.

    2106                 :             : 
    2107                 :             : /**
    2108                 :             :  * Check whether all of this transaction's input scripts succeed.
    2109                 :             :  *
    2110                 :             :  * This involves ECDSA signature checks so can be computationally intensive. This function should
    2111                 :             :  * only be called after the cheap sanity checks in CheckTxInputs passed.
    2112                 :             :  *
    2113                 :             :  * If pvChecks is not nullptr, script checks are pushed onto it instead of being performed inline. Any
    2114                 :             :  * script checks which are not necessary (eg due to script execution cache hits) are, obviously,
    2115                 :             :  * not pushed onto pvChecks/run.
    2116                 :             :  *
    2117                 :             :  * Setting cacheSigStore/cacheFullScriptStore to false will remove elements from the corresponding cache
    2118                 :             :  * which are matched. This is useful for checking blocks where we will likely never need the cache
    2119                 :             :  * entry again.
    2120                 :             :  *
    2121                 :             :  * Note that we may set state.reason to NOT_STANDARD for extra soft-fork flags in flags, block-checking
    2122                 :             :  * callers should probably reset it to CONSENSUS in such cases.
    2123                 :             :  *
    2124                 :             :  * Non-static (and redeclared) in src/test/txvalidationcache_tests.cpp
    2125                 :             :  */
    2126                 :      272003 : bool CheckInputScripts(const CTransaction& tx, TxValidationState& state,

    2267                 :       15398 : DisconnectResult Chainstate::DisconnectBlock(const CBlock& block, const CBlockIndex* pindex, CCoinsViewCache& view)
    2268                 :             : {
    2269                 :       15398 :     AssertLockHeld(::cs_main);
    2270                 :       15398 :     bool fClean = true;
    2271                 :             : 
    2272                 :       15398 :     CBlockUndo blockUndo;
    2273   [ +  -  +  + ]:       15398 :     if (!m_blockman.UndoReadFromDisk(blockUndo, *pindex)) {
    2274         [ +  - ]:           3 :         LogError("DisconnectBlock(): failure reading undo data\n");
    2275                 :             :         return DISCONNECT_FAILED;
    2276                 :             :     }
    2277                 :             : 
    2278         [ -  + ]:       15395 :     if (blockUndo.vtxundo.size() + 1 != block.vtx.size()) {
    2279         [ #  # ]:           0 :         LogError("DisconnectBlock(): block and undo data inconsistent\n");
    2280                 :             :         return DISCONNECT_FAILED;
    2281                 :             :     }
    2282                 :             : 
    2283                 :             :     // Ignore blocks that contain transactions which are 'overwritten' by later transactions,
    2284                 :             :     // unless those are already completely spent.
    2285                 :             :     // See https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/issues/22596 for additional information.
    2286                 :             :     // Note: the blocks specified here are different than the ones used in ConnectBlock because DisconnectBlock
    2287                 :             :     // unwinds the blocks in reverse. As a result, the inconsistency is not discovered until the earlier
    2288                 :             :     // blocks with the duplicate coinbase transactions are disconnected.
    2289   [ -  +  -  - ]:       15395 :     bool fEnforceBIP30 = !((pindex->nHeight==91722 && pindex->GetBlockHash() == uint256{"00000000000271a2dc26e7667f8419f2e15416dc6955e5a6c6cdf3f2574dd08e"}) ||
    2290   [ -  +  -  - ]:       15395 :                            (pindex->nHeight==91812 && pindex->GetBlockHash() == uint256{"00000000000af0aed4792b1acee3d966af36cf5def14935db8de83d6f9306f2f"}));
    2291                 :             : 
    2292                 :             :     // undo transactions in reverse order
    2293         [ +  + ]:       40847 :     for (int i = block.vtx.size() - 1; i >= 0; i--) {
    2294                 :       25452 :         const CTransaction &tx = *(block.vtx[i]);
    2295                 :       25452 :         Txid hash = tx.GetHash();
    2296                 :       25452 :         bool is_coinbase = tx.IsCoinBase();
    2297                 :       25452 :         bool is_bip30_exception = (is_coinbase && !fEnforceBIP30);
    2298                 :             : 
    2299                 :             :         // Check that all outputs are available and match the outputs in the block itself
    2300                 :             :         // exactly.
    2301         [ +  + ]:       72409 :         for (size_t o = 0; o < tx.vout.size(); o++) {
    2302         [ +  + ]:       46957 :             if (!tx.vout[o].scriptPubKey.IsUnspendable()) {
    2303                 :       32447 :                 COutPoint out(hash, o);
    2304                 :       32447 :                 Coin coin;
    2305         [ +  - ]:       32447 :                 bool is_spent = view.SpendCoin(out, &coin);

    2364                 :      192568 : static unsigned int GetBlockScriptFlags(const CBlockIndex& block_index, const ChainstateManager& chainman)

    2366                 :      192568 :     const Consensus::Params& consensusparams = chainman.GetConsensus();
    2367                 :             : 
    2368                 :             :     // BIP16 didn't become active until Apr 1 2012 (on mainnet, and
    2369                 :             :     // retroactively applied to testnet)
    2370                 :             :     // However, only one historical block violated the P2SH rules (on both
    2371                 :             :     // mainnet and testnet).
    2372                 :             :     // Similarly, only one historical block violated the TAPROOT rules on
    2373                 :             :     // mainnet.
    2374                 :             :     // For simplicity, always leave P2SH+WITNESS+TAPROOT on except for the two
    2375                 :             :     // violating blocks.

    2404                 :             : 
    2405                 :             : 
    2406                 :             : /** Apply the effects of this block (with given index) on the UTXO set represented by coins.
    2407                 :             :  *  Validity checks that depend on the UTXO set are also done; ConnectBlock()
    2408                 :             :  *  can fail if those validity checks fail (among other reasons). */
    2409                 :      159912 : bool Chainstate::ConnectBlock(const CBlock& block, BlockValidationState& state, CBlockIndex* pindex,
    2410                 :             :                                CCoinsViewCache& view, bool fJustCheck)

    2412                 :      159912 :     AssertLockHeld(cs_main);

    2420                 :      159912 :     const CChainParams& params{m_chainman.GetParams()};
    2421                 :             : 
    2422                 :             :     // Check it again in case a previous version let a bad block in
    2423                 :             :     // NOTE: We don't currently (re-)invoke ContextualCheckBlock() or
    2424                 :             :     // ContextualCheckBlockHeader() here. This means that if we add a new
    2425                 :             :     // consensus rule that is enforced in one of those two functions, then we
    2426                 :             :     // may have let in a block that violates the rule prior to updating the
    2427                 :             :     // software, and we would NOT be enforcing the rule here. Fully solving
    2428                 :             :     // upgrade from one software version to the next after a consensus rule
    2429                 :             :     // change is potentially tricky and issue-specific (see NeedsRedownload()
    2430                 :             :     // for one approach that was used for BIP 141 deployment).
    2431                 :             :     // Also, currently the rule against blocks more than 2 hours in the future
    2432                 :             :     // is enforced in ContextualCheckBlockHeader(); we wouldn't want to
    2433                 :             :     // re-enforce that rule here (at least until we make it impossible for
    2434                 :             :     // the clock to go backward).
    2435         [ -  + ]:      159912 :     if (!CheckBlock(block, state, params.GetConsensus(), !fJustCheck, !fJustCheck)) {
    2436         [ #  # ]:           0 :         if (state.GetResult() == BlockValidationResult::BLOCK_MUTATED) {

    2438                 :             :             // corrupted, so this should be impossible unless we're having hardware

    2452                 :             :     // Special case for the genesis block, skipping connection of its transactions
    2453                 :             :     // (its coinbase is unspendable)

    2459                 :             : 
    2460                 :      159398 :     bool fScriptChecks = true;
    2461         [ +  + ]:      159398 :     if (!m_chainman.AssumedValidBlock().IsNull()) {
    2462                 :             :         // We've been configured with the hash of a block which has been externally verified to have a valid history.
    2463                 :             :         // A suitable default value is included with the software and updated from time to time.  Because validity
    2464                 :             :         //  relative to a piece of software is an objective fact these defaults can be easily reviewed.
    2465                 :             :         // This setting doesn't force the selection of any particular chain but makes validating some faster by
    2466                 :             :         //  effectively caching the result of part of the verification.
    2467         [ +  + ]:        2442 :         BlockMap::const_iterator it{m_blockman.m_block_index.find(m_chainman.AssumedValidBlock())};
    2468         [ +  + ]:        2442 :         if (it != m_blockman.m_block_index.end()) {
    2469                 :        2304 :             if (it->second.GetAncestor(pindex->nHeight) == pindex &&
    2470   [ +  +  +  - ]:        2304 :                 m_chainman.m_best_header->GetAncestor(pindex->nHeight) == pindex &&
    2471         [ +  - ]:         204 :                 m_chainman.m_best_header->nChainWork >= m_chainman.MinimumChainWork()) {
    2472                 :             :                 // This block is a member of the assumed verified chain and an ancestor of the best header.
    2473                 :             :                 // Script verification is skipped when connecting blocks under the
    2474                 :             :                 // assumevalid block. Assuming the assumevalid block is valid this
    2475                 :             :                 // is safe because block merkle hashes are still computed and checked,
    2476                 :             :                 // Of course, if an assumed valid block is invalid due to false scriptSigs
    2477                 :             :                 // this optimization would allow an invalid chain to be accepted.
    2478                 :             :                 // The equivalent time check discourages hash power from extorting the network via DOS attack
    2479                 :             :                 //  into accepting an invalid block through telling users they must manually set assumevalid.
    2480                 :             :                 //  Requiring a software change or burying the invalid block, regardless of the setting, makes
    2481                 :             :                 //  it hard to hide the implication of the demand.  This also avoids having release candidates
    2482                 :             :                 //  that are hardly doing any signature verification at all in testing without having to
    2483                 :             :                 //  artificially set the default assumed verified block further back.
    2484                 :             :                 // The test against the minimum chain work prevents the skipping when denied access to any chain at
    2485                 :             :                 //  least as good as the expected chain.
    2486                 :         204 :                 fScriptChecks = (GetBlockProofEquivalentTime(*m_chainman.m_best_header, *pindex, *m_chainman.m_best_header, params.GetConsensus()) <= 60 * 60 * 24 * 7 * 2);

    2488                 :             :         }
    2489                 :             :     }
    2490                 :             : 
    2491                 :      159398 :     const auto time_1{SteadyClock::now()};
    2492                 :      159398 :     m_chainman.time_check += time_1 - time_start;
    2493         [ +  - ]:      159398 :     LogDebug(BCLog::BENCH, "    - Sanity checks: %.2fms [%.2fs (%.2fms/blk)]\n",
    2494                 :             :              Ticks<MillisecondsDouble>(time_1 - time_start),
    2495                 :             :              Ticks<SecondsDouble>(m_chainman.time_check),
    2496                 :             :              Ticks<MillisecondsDouble>(m_chainman.time_check) / m_chainman.num_blocks_total);
    2497                 :             : 
    2498                 :             :     // Do not allow blocks that contain transactions which 'overwrite' older transactions,
    2499                 :             :     // unless those are already completely spent.
    2500                 :             :     // If such overwrites are allowed, coinbases and transactions depending upon those
    2501                 :             :     // can be duplicated to remove the ability to spend the first instance -- even after
    2502                 :             :     // being sent to another address.
    2503                 :             :     // See BIP30, CVE-2012-1909, and http://r6.ca/blog/20120206T005236Z.html for more information.
    2504                 :             :     // This rule was originally applied to all blocks with a timestamp after March 15, 2012, 0:00 UTC.
    2505                 :             :     // Now that the whole chain is irreversibly beyond that time it is applied to all blocks except the
    2506                 :             :     // two in the chain that violate it. This prevents exploiting the issue against nodes during their
    2507                 :             :     // initial block download.
    2508                 :      159398 :     bool fEnforceBIP30 = !IsBIP30Repeat(*pindex);
    2509                 :             : 
    2510                 :             :     // Once BIP34 activated it was not possible to create new duplicate coinbases and thus other than starting
    2511                 :             :     // with the 2 existing duplicate coinbase pairs, not possible to create overwriting txs.  But by the
    2512                 :             :     // time BIP34 activated, in each of the existing pairs the duplicate coinbase had overwritten the first
    2513                 :             :     // before the first had been spent.  Since those coinbases are sufficiently buried it's no longer possible to create further
    2514                 :             :     // duplicate transactions descending from the known pairs either.
    2515                 :             :     // If we're on the known chain at height greater than where BIP34 activated, we can save the db accesses needed for the BIP30 check.
    2516                 :             : 
    2517                 :             :     // BIP34 requires that a block at height X (block X) has its coinbase
    2518                 :             :     // scriptSig start with a CScriptNum of X (indicated height X).  The above
    2519                 :             :     // logic of no longer requiring BIP30 once BIP34 activates is flawed in the
    2520                 :             :     // case that there is a block X before the BIP34 height of 227,931 which has
    2521                 :             :     // an indicated height Y where Y is greater than X.  The coinbase for block
    2522                 :             :     // X would also be a valid coinbase for block Y, which could be a BIP30
    2523                 :             :     // violation.  An exhaustive search of all mainnet coinbases before the
    2524                 :             :     // BIP34 height which have an indicated height greater than the block height
    2525                 :             :     // reveals many occurrences. The 3 lowest indicated heights found are
    2526                 :             :     // 209,921, 490,897, and 1,983,702 and thus coinbases for blocks at these 3
    2527                 :             :     // heights would be the first opportunity for BIP30 to be violated.
    2528                 :             : 
    2529                 :             :     // The search reveals a great many blocks which have an indicated height
    2530                 :             :     // greater than 1,983,702, so we simply remove the optimization to skip
    2531                 :             :     // BIP30 checking for blocks at height 1,983,702 or higher.  Before we reach
    2532                 :             :     // that block in another 25 years or so, we should take advantage of a
    2533                 :             :     // future consensus change to do a new and improved version of BIP34 that
    2534                 :             :     // will actually prevent ever creating any duplicate coinbases in the
    2535                 :             :     // future.
    2536                 :      159398 :     static constexpr int BIP34_IMPLIES_BIP30_LIMIT = 1983702;
    2537                 :             : 
    2538                 :             :     // There is no potential to create a duplicate coinbase at block 209,921
    2539                 :             :     // because this is still before the BIP34 height and so explicit BIP30
    2540                 :             :     // checking is still active.
    2541                 :             : 
    2542                 :             :     // The final case is block 176,684 which has an indicated height of
    2543                 :             :     // 490,897. Unfortunately, this issue was not discovered until about 2 weeks
    2544                 :             :     // before block 490,897 so there was not much opportunity to address this
    2545                 :             :     // case other than to carefully analyze it and determine it would not be a
    2546                 :             :     // problem. Block 490,897 was, in fact, mined with a different coinbase than
    2547                 :             :     // block 176,684, but it is important to note that even if it hadn't been or
    2548                 :             :     // is remined on an alternate fork with a duplicate coinbase, we would still
    2549                 :             :     // not run into a BIP30 violation.  This is because the coinbase for 176,684
    2550                 :             :     // is spent in block 185,956 in transaction
    2551                 :             :     // d4f7fbbf92f4a3014a230b2dc70b8058d02eb36ac06b4a0736d9d60eaa9e8781.  This
    2552                 :             :     // spending transaction can't be duplicated because it also spends coinbase
    2553                 :             :     // 0328dd85c331237f18e781d692c92de57649529bd5edf1d01036daea32ffde29.  This
    2554                 :             :     // coinbase has an indicated height of over 4.2 billion, and wouldn't be
    2555                 :             :     // duplicatable until that height, and it's currently impossible to create a
    2556                 :             :     // chain that long. Nevertheless we may wish to consider a future soft fork
    2557                 :             :     // which retroactively prevents block 490,897 from creating a duplicate
    2558                 :             :     // coinbase. The two historical BIP30 violations often provide a confusing
    2559                 :             :     // edge case when manipulating the UTXO and it would be simpler not to have
    2560                 :             :     // another edge case to deal with.
    2561                 :             : 
    2562                 :             :     // testnet3 has no blocks before the BIP34 height with indicated heights
    2563                 :             :     // post BIP34 before approximately height 486,000,000. After block
    2564                 :             :     // 1,983,702 testnet3 starts doing unnecessary BIP30 checking again.
    2565         [ -  + ]:      159398 :     assert(pindex->pprev);
    2566                 :      159398 :     CBlockIndex* pindexBIP34height = pindex->pprev->GetAncestor(params.GetConsensus().BIP34Height);
    2567                 :             :     //Only continue to enforce if we're below BIP34 activation height or the block hash at that height doesn't correspond.
    2568   [ +  -  +  +  :      159398 :     fEnforceBIP30 = fEnforceBIP30 && (!pindexBIP34height || !(pindexBIP34height->GetBlockHash() == params.GetConsensus().BIP34Hash));
                   -  + ]

    2570                 :             :     // TODO: Remove BIP30 checking from block height 1,983,702 on, once we have a
    2571                 :             :     // consensus change that ensures coinbases at those heights cannot
    2572                 :             :     // duplicate earlier coinbases.
    2573         [ #  # ]:           0 :     if (fEnforceBIP30 || pindex->nHeight >= BIP34_IMPLIES_BIP30_LIMIT) {
    2574         [ +  + ]:      381614 :         for (const auto& tx : block.vtx) {
    2575         [ +  + ]:      843994 :             for (size_t o = 0; o < tx->vout.size(); o++) {

    2580                 :             :             }
    2581                 :             :         }
    2582                 :             :     }
    2583                 :             :

    2597                 :             :              Ticks<SecondsDouble>(m_chainman.time_forks),
    2598                 :             :              Ticks<MillisecondsDouble>(m_chainman.time_forks) / m_chainman.num_blocks_total);

    2600                 :      159397 :     CBlockUndo blockundo;
    2601                 :             : 
    2602                 :             :     // Precomputed transaction data pointers must not be invalidated
    2603                 :             :     // until after `control` has run the script checks (potentially
    2604                 :             :     // in multiple threads). Preallocate the vector size so a new allocation
    2605                 :             :     // doesn't invalidate pointers into the vector, and keep txsdata in scope

    3447                 :             :     // because this function periodically releases cs_main so that it does not lock up other threads for too long

    3940                 :             : 
    3941                 :             : /** CheckWitnessMalleation performs checks for block malleation with regard to

    3943                 :             :  *
    3944                 :             :  * Note: If the witness commitment is expected (i.e. `expect_witness_commitment

    4228                 :      153949 :                                       pindexPrev->GetMedianTimePast() :
    4229                 :        1402 :                                       block.GetBlockTime()};

    4231                 :             :     // Check that all transactions are finalized
    4232         [ +  + ]:      371242 :     for (const auto& tx : block.vtx) {

    4234   [ +  -  +  - ]:           7 :             return state.Invalid(BlockValidationResult::BLOCK_CONSENSUS, "bad-txns-nonfinal", "non-final transaction");
    4235                 :             :         }
    4236                 :             :     }
    4237                 :             : 
    4238                 :             :     // Enforce rule that the coinbase starts with serialized block height
    4239         [ +  + ]:      155344 :     if (DeploymentActiveAfter(pindexPrev, chainman, Consensus::DEPLOYMENT_HEIGHTINCB))
    4240                 :             :     {
    4241         [ +  - ]:      155197 :         CScript expect = CScript() << nHeight;
    4242   [ +  +  -  +  :      310394 :         if (block.vtx[0]->vin[0].scriptSig.size() < expect.size() ||
             +  +  +  - ]
    4243   [ +  +  -  + ]:      310392 :             !std::equal(expect.begin(), expect.end(), block.vtx[0]->vin[0].scriptSig.begin())) {
    4244   [ +  -  +  -  :           1 :             return state.Invalid(BlockValidationResult::BLOCK_CONSENSUS, "bad-cb-height", "block height mismatch in coinbase");
                   +  - ]
    4245                 :             :         }
    4246                 :      155197 :     }
    4247                 :             : 
    4248                 :             :     // Validation for witness commitments.
    4249                 :             :     // * We compute the witness hash (which is the hash including witnesses) of all the block's transactions, except the
    4250                 :             :     //   coinbase (where 0x0000....0000 is used instead).
    4251                 :             :     // * The coinbase scriptWitness is a stack of a single 32-byte vector, containing a witness reserved value (unconstrained).
    4252                 :             :     // * We build a merkle tree with all those witness hashes as leaves (similar to the hashMerkleRoot in the block header).
    4253                 :             :     // * There must be at least one output whose scriptPubKey is a single 36-byte push, the first 4 bytes of which are
    4254                 :             :     //   {0xaa, 0x21, 0xa9, 0xed}, and the following 32 bytes are SHA256^2(witness root, witness reserved value). In case there are
    4255                 :             :     //   multiple, the last one is used.
    4256         [ +  + ]:      155343 :     if (!CheckWitnessMalleation(block, DeploymentActiveAfter(pindexPrev, chainman, Consensus::DEPLOYMENT_SEGWIT), state)) {
    4257                 :             :         return false;
    4258                 :             :     }
    4259                 :             : 
    4260                 :             :     // After the coinbase witness reserved value and commitment are verified,
    4261                 :             :     // we can check if the block weight passes (before we've checked the
    4262                 :             :     // coinbase witness, it would be possible for the weight to be too
    4263                 :             :     // large by filling up the coinbase witness, which doesn't change
    4264                 :             :     // the block hash, so we couldn't mark the block as permanently
    4265                 :             :     // failed).
    4266         [ +  + ]:      155335 :     if (GetBlockWeight(block) > MAX_BLOCK_WEIGHT) {
    4267   [ +  -  +  - ]:           1 :         return state.Invalid(BlockValidationResult::BLOCK_CONSENSUS, "bad-blk-weight", strprintf("%s : weight limit failed", __func__));
    4268                 :             :     }
    4269                 :             : 
    4270                 :             :     return true;
    4271                 :             : }
    4272                 :             : 
    4273                 :      231253 : bool ChainstateManager::AcceptBlockHeader(const CBlockHeader& block, BlockValidationState& state, CBlockIndex** ppindex, bool min_pow_checked)

    4316                 :             :          * invalid (m_failed_blocks), then mark pindexPrev and any blocks between
    4317                 :             :          * them as failed. For example:
    4318                 :             :          *
    4319                 :             :          *                D3
    4320                 :             :          *              /
    4321                 :             :          *      B2 - C2
    4322                 :             :          *    /         \
    4323                 :             :          *  A             D2 - E2 - F2
    4324                 :             :          *    \
    4325                 :             :          *      B1 - C1 - D1 - E1
    4326                 :             :          *
    4327                 :             :          * In the case that we attempted to reorg from E1 to F2, only to find
    4328                 :             :          * C2 to be invalid, we would mark D2, E2, and F2 as BLOCK_FAILED_CHILD
    4329                 :             :          * but NOT D3 (it was not in any of our candidate sets at the time).
    4330                 :             :          *
    4331                 :             :          * In any case D3 will also be marked as BLOCK_FAILED_CHILD at restart
    4332                 :             :          * in LoadBlockIndex.
    4333                 :             :          */
    4334   [ +  -  +  + ]:      123761 :         if (!pindexPrev->IsValid(BLOCK_VALID_SCRIPTS)) {

    4552         [ +  - ]:      118176 :         LOCK(cs_main);

    4554                 :             :         // Skipping AcceptBlock() for CheckBlock() failures means that we will never mark a block as invalid if
    4555                 :             :         // CheckBlock() fails.  This is protective against consensus failure if there are any unknown forms of block

    4557                 :             :         // https://lists.linuxfoundation.org/pipermail/bitcoin-dev/2019-February/016697.html.  Because CheckBlock() is
    4558                 :             :         // not very expensive, the anti-DoS benefits of caching failure (of a definitely-invalid block) are not substantial.

    4903                 :           0 :                 return false;
    4904                 :             :             }
    4905                 :             :             // If DISCONNECT_UNCLEAN is returned, it means a non-existing UTXO was deleted, or an existing UTXO was
    4906                 :             :             // overwritten. It corresponds to cases where the block-to-be-disconnect never had all its operations
    4907                 :             :             // applied to the UTXO set. However, as both writing a UTXO and deleting a UTXO are idempotent operations,
    4908                 :             :             // the result is still a version of the UTXO set with the effects of that block undone.
    4909                 :           0 :         }

    5180                 :             :                 // historical bugs added extra data to the block files that does not deserialize cleanly.
    5181                 :             :                 // commonly this data is between readable blocks, but it does not really matter. such data is not fatal to the import process.
    5182                 :             :                 // the code that reads the block files deals with invalid data by simply ignoring it.
    5183                 :             :                 // it continues to search for the next {4 byte magic message start bytes + 4 byte length + block} that does deserialize cleanly
    5184                 :             :                 // and passes all of the other block validation checks dealing with POW and the merkle root, etc...
    5185                 :             :                 // we merely note with this informational log message when unexpected data is encountered.
    5186                 :             :                 // we could also be experiencing a storage system read error, or a read of a previous bad write. these are possible, but
    5187                 :             :                 // less likely scenarios. we don't have enough information to tell a difference here.
    5188                 :             :                 // the reindex process is not the place to attempt to clean and/or compact the block files. if so desired, a studious node operator
    5189                 :             :                 // may use knowledge of the fact that the block files are not entirely pristine in order to prepare a set of pristine, and
    5190                 :             :                 // perhaps ordered, block files for later reindexing.

    5705                 :             :     // Cache percentages to allocate to each chainstate.
    5706                 :             :     //
    5707                 :             :     // These particular percentages don't matter so much since they will only be
    5708                 :             :     // relevant during snapshot activation; caches are rebalanced at the conclusion of
    5709                 :             :     // this function. We want to give (essentially) all available cache capacity to the
    5710                 :             :     // snapshot to aid the bulk load later in this function.
    5711                 :          36 :     static constexpr double IBD_CACHE_PERC = 0.01;
    5712                 :          36 :     static constexpr double SNAPSHOT_CACHE_PERC = 0.99;
    5713                 :             : 
    5714                 :          36 :     {
    5715                 :          36 :         LOCK(::cs_main);

    5717                 :             :         //
    5718                 :             :         // Allocate the majority of the cache to the incoming snapshot chainstate, since
    5719                 :             :         // (optimistically) getting to its tip will be the top priority. We'll need to call
    5720                 :             :         // `MaybeRebalanceCaches()` once we're done with this function to ensure
